Germany: Döner (it originated there in its current form) or Weißwurst
GB: Beef Wellington
France: Too hard but gun to my head, it's rilette. Coq au Vin and, Canard confit and Foie Gras close. Or croque monsieurs... God I love the French cuisine.
US: Barbecue or Gumbo
Spain: Inferior to Italy and Portugal, but patatas bravas and chorizo be good

Truly I love almost all cuisines but French, Italian, Mexican and Portugese are in a different league. Also Eastern European (including Greek and Turkish) is vastly underrated. Asian food cannot compare in terms of variety, despite utilising way more herbs than Italian (for example) it's all the same sloppa in the end if you judge by total diversity of foods. threads.com: After my father died, my mother would make an effort to make us breakfast every morning (and by this I mean most mornings, excluding holidays (E.G Christmas, Easter, Etc.) Although my mother was never religious after my father’s death (he was devoutly religious (Episcopalian) as his father was a Minister) we nevertheless celebrated these holidays in a secular manner)). On holidays we would often go out to eat at a restaurant (for the sake of brevity I will not take the time to say which restaurants we patronized although there were restaurants that we patronized!), when there was sufficient money to do so (my mother, as she did not graduate college, worked a low wage job (and in fact often worked multiple jobs (although it only became necessary to do so after my sister was born))). On one such occasion (patronizing a restaurant (a local establishment called Schmuckers)) I decided to order the bacon and the eggs (for breakfast). My mother, I could sense, although she did not express it directly, as she was often a rather reserved person, particularly after the death of my father, that my mother was disappointed and upset with what I had ordered (bacon and eggs (for breakfast)). I did not, for many years (in fact not until my mother had passed away (God rest her soul)) discover the reason why she was angry and disappointed with the bacon and eggs I had ordered. The story is not, I think, of sufficiently broad interest to relay here. Nevertheless, I certainty learned my lesson! When it comes to family, more of them know you than you know yourself!

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
There are burgers with extra meat, extra bacon, extra cheese, extra veggies, etc.
...but why aren't there burgers with extra buns?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18581712
The top bun acts to hold all the contents between it and the bottom bun. Trying to stack things on it is difficult because it is convex in shape, whereas the bottom bun is (mostly) plane/flat, so it can easily support structures above it without toppling or slipping off. This is why you can have multiple bottom buns (support structures), but not multiple top buns. The theoretical burger in your image would have an unstable top bun unless manually squeezed down or skewered. It would also be more troublesome to eat compared to a double-bottom-bun burger due to it not having as many juices/sauces to soak up and moisten for easier consumption. A similar issue would occur with double bottom buns directly stacked (as opposed to layered, ala Big Mac). Overall, the additional bun design is inconvenient, and most people do not desire a more bread-to-burger contents ratio, so it wouldn't be a big seller either, outside of joke purchases for social media.

threads.sub: You'll cowards don't even grow squash
threads.com:
I notice that /ck/ has an undercurrent of food-related prepping and gardening. But many of you don't really know WHAT to grow, beyond the obvious stuff like potatoes or corn. The answer is squash. Squashes can be cleaned and stored for up to a year after harvest. They are full of nutrients. They are versatile in terms of cooking and recipes. They can be canned or stored for longer periods of time. And they aren't very difficult to grow in temperate climates.

There are thousands of varieties of squash, but beginners should start with the Cucurbita maxima, AKA the 'blue hubbard.' Blue hubbards have dense, rich flesh which is prized for its texture and taste. They grow to respectable sizes, but aren't absurdly huge like pumpkins (a late-season healthy Hubbard should be anywhere from 10 to 20lbs / 4.5-9kg, or a bit bigger if they start earlier in the season). They have a rugged outer skin which helps ward off predators and damage. And they have a good aesthetic in general. Peeled and cubed hubbard fits great in stews and soups.

If you have limited experience with squashes or gardening, this is a good way to start. You can easily grow a dozen or more mature hubbards from a small number of plants and their vines, even with relatively limited space. That's a couple hundred pounds of fresh, high-quality, nutrient-rich food. And beyond that, there are many other squashes to grow.

You WILL grow some squashes the next time your local planting season comes around - right, /ck/?

This is one of the biggest reasons to grow stuff yourself, and it's often overlooked. Yes being able to pick stuff super ripe and really fresh is a huge deal, especially for some plants. But growing varieties of your iwn choice is massive. Supermarket varieties are chosen for high yield, regular size/shape, and ease of transport and storage, often at the expense of flavor and texture. But there are hundreds, or thousands of varieties of many vegetables and fruits, and many are still bred to be delicious. It's night and day quite often.

threads.com: Is pipe smoking /ck/? I mean, it's technically cooking something. And your taste buds are part of the experience.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18580391
no. filtered pipes directly absorb tar and smoke via their replaceable filters. Pipes are carved from briarwood for two reasons: briarwood is naturally fire resistant (briarwood pipes are made from the root of a specific Mediterranean shrub that can regrow after brush fires). Secondly, briarwood is porous and absorbs a lot of tar and moisture when properly smoked, giving you a very cool and dry smoke. Corncob pipes do the latter much better but have a much shorter lifespan while briarwood pipes will literally outlive you. Alternatively, meerschaum and clay pipes are said to smoke even cooler but I've never tried one.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>18579629
Slav here. A local panasian store started to sell tofu, kimchi and other pickled veggies made my some local asian expats. Good stuff and cheap comparing to the canned imported and some chef gourmet local restaurant-made i tried. It's great with everything. Sweet-ish grains like pearl barley, bulgur, small couscous. Latter is interesting because you can mix in the thinly shredded kimchi before pouring the hot brine/water in. Found it interesting with the wheat grains (berries). You can make the polenta (forma de fritta) with same shredded kimchi as a stuffing. Didn't really get it with the buckwheat. Easy choice to add to the beans stew like Georgian lobio. Nice addition to savoury pie stuffing, meat, spinach+cream cheese or quark. Smoked ham soup, but instead of basic cabbage you use kimchi or a mix. After all, it's just a spicy cabbage.
